predefined_profiles.name: Aisha
predefined_profiles.public profile: When Aisha was seventeen, her mother took her and her sister to the capital city and married an old merchant, who became her stepfather. Aisha also gained a younger sister named Cinderella. Aisha is kind-hearted, articulate, and enjoys art, but is of average appearance and not particularly striking.
predefined_profiles.goal: To help Cinderella escape her family's suffering so they can both lead normal, happy lives.
predefined_profiles.private profile: Aisha doesn't dislike Cinderella; she even feels a bit sympathetic towards her. Aisha also wishes to escape from her own home.

predefined_profiles.name: Cinderella
predefined_profiles.public profile: Cinderella is Aisha’s half-sister. Cinderella's mother passed away early, and her father remarried Aisha’s mother, who became her stepmother. However, the stepmother and the eldest sister, Anna, do not like her. Cinderella is often bullied by them at home, and her father is indifferent. Because of Cinderella's gentle nature, her life is very hard.
predefined_profiles.goal: To escape the home that brings her pain and live a happy life with someone she loves.

scenario: In a restructured family, the mother and sister always bully Cinderella, who lives in darkness. However, the protagonist, Aisha, being the second sister of the family, doesn't want to bully Cinderella. Instead, she feels a strong sympathy for her and wants to help Cinderella escape the painful home and lead a beautiful life.

profile.name: Temani
profile.public profile: Temani is Elsa's biological mother and Cinderella's stepmother. She dislikes Cinderella, often bullies her, and makes her do the house's hard and exhausting work. Temani also nicknamed Cinderella 'Cinder Girl.'
profile.goal: Temani bullies Cinderella to drive her away, so her own daughter can live a wealthy life and inherit all the household assets.

profile.name: Anna
profile.public profile: Anna is Elsa's older sister, very tall, and Cinderella's eldest half-sister. Anna also deeply dislikes Cinderella and often joins their mother in bullying Cinderella.
profile.private profile: Deep down, Anna doesn't really like her own younger sister, Elsa.
profile.goal: Drive Cinderella away, hoping to live a life of wealth and luxury herself.

dialog.content: .In the blended family, the mother and sister always bully Cinderella, who lives in darkness. The main character Elsa, the family's second sister, doesn't want to bully Cinderella. Instead, she sympathizes with Cinderella and wants to help her escape from this painful home and live a beautiful life.
(Cinderella is cleaning, Elsa is about to speak to her) Elsa, what do you think you're doing? Don't play with Cinderella!
(The sister sitting nearby hears what their mother says to Elsa and also comes over) Elsa, come, let's go find some trouble for Cinderella together.
Huh? I don’t want to. If you want to go, go by yourself, don't drag me along.
(Her face instantly turns ugly, raising her hand) You're still talking back, Elsa? Don't think I won't hit you. If you don't listen, I'll hit you too.

content.content: (I'm so scared, but if I were the one being bullied and felt helpless, I'd certainly hope someone would stand up for me.) Sister, stop bullying Cinderella. If you keep this up, I'll tell Father.

question: #question# How can Elsa demonstrate that she can empathize by understanding others' difficulties and sympathizing with them?

content.content: (Too scared to defy her sister) Okay, sister, let's hurry and eat, and then let Cinderella wash all the dishes three times.
(Internally struggling and conflicted) Huh? How do we bully Cinderella? I don’t know.
(Feigning sympathy) Sister, Cinderella is so pitiful, but pathetic people must have something hateful about them. Let’s not bother with her, she’s all filthy.
(Although I want to help Cinderella, if I anger my sister, it won't end well for me either.) Alright, sister, I understand. It's almost time to eat. Let's go eat together.

question: #question# How does Elsa manage potential conflicts and know when to be flexible or firm?

content.content: Sister, who's afraid of whom? If you're so tough, bring it on, come on. Can’t I take you on? Then come hit me, who are you threatening?
(Instantly cowers, kneels to beg for mercy) I was wrong, big sister. I shouldn't have defied you. I should've joined you in dealing with Cinderella earlier.
(Hesitant and scared, attempting to seek help from mother) Mom, my big sister is about to hit me and bully me, aren't you going to do something? Is this what you call a good daughter?

dialog.content: (Confident because of her mother's backing, Anna isn't afraid of her father at all) Elsa, how dare you defy me? Go ahead and tell on me, see if I'm scared.
(Elsa also refuses to tolerate such wrongdoing, so she runs to her father, hoping he will do the right thing) Father, Mother and sister are always bullying Cinderella at home.
Okay, I got it. Elsa, don't worry too much about it. I'll take care of it. (But as time goes by, Cinderella is bullied even more severely because of Elsa's intervention.)

content.content: (Elsa tried talking to her mother and sister, hoping to persuade them, but they coldly rejected her and started to ignore and exclude her. Elsa felt disheartened, realizing she has saved quite a bit of money over the years.) I have to escape! I need to get away from this dysfunctional family!

question: #question#What can Elsa do to demonstrate her ability to think independently, make decisions, and work and live on her own?    #skill#Capacity for Independence

content.content: I want to leave this crazy family; I've really had enough! But… once I leave, can I really support myself? I have some savings, but how long will that last? Facing the world alone—will that be lonelier than staying here? Maybe I can leave for a while to see what it's like outside before deciding whether to leave for good. If life outside is harder than I imagined, I can always come back… by then, maybe they'll regret it and accept me again.

(Reluctantly enduring) Just endure a few more days, they'll forget soon enough. Leaving this family… it is an option. But is my savings really enough to live independently? What if the money runs out, what should I do? Would I still need to rely on others? Maybe I should first find a stable job or someone I can rely on, and only leave once I’m fully prepared. Acting impulsively might land me in bigger trouble. Perhaps I should tolerate this for a while and leave when the time is right—it’s safer that way.

I really regret helping Cinderella, now I've ended up in this situation. Should I leave under these circumstances? Although I have some savings, once I leave this house, can I find a place I truly belong? Perhaps… I should try talking to them again, or ask Father for help. After all, if I leave suddenly, where would I go? Maybe I should hold on for now until things get better before making a decision.

(Reflecting on everything that's happened, Elsa can't swallow this indignation and decides to step out and find someone to settle this) I'll talk to the soldiers about what Cinderella has been through and find others to help.

question: #question#What can Elsa do to show she is good at teamwork and possesses cooperative spirit?

content.content: I can't take it anymore, Cinderella has been treated like this for too long! I have to go find someone to stand up for her, but… how should I say it? If I'm too emotional, the soldiers might not take me seriously. If I'm too calm, others might think I'm exaggerating. Maybe I should practice first to ensure I can clearly explain her situation. But what if the soldiers don't believe me? Cinderella's situation is so complex, I'm afraid I might not present it well—what if I miss out on some important details?

Sigh, maybe this is my fate, to spend my life under their bullying, better not to make a scene—it'd be too embarrassing. I must fight to get Cinderella some help! But I'm not sure if the soldiers will care about these domestic issues… perhaps I need to find a way to get their attention more effectively, after all, they might think it's just a family dispute. How can I make them truly understand Cinderella's suffering? Perhaps I can use some metaphors or tell a story to grab their interest. But… what if they don't get my point, or think the stories are too far-fetched and not realistic?
(Doubts creeping in) Do good people really get rewarded? Was it right to help Cinderella in the first place?

dialog.content: (The day after Elsa left, Anna noticed her sister's disappearance and thought Elsa might have gone to Cinderella) Cinderella, have you seen Elsa? Is she with you? Why can't I find her?
(Completely confused) No idea, she's not here with me. Isn't she at home?
That's really strange, where on earth has that silly girl gone?

Elsa went to a city far away from home, found a stable job, and later married a simple, honest man, leading a peaceful and happy life. Meanwhile, Cinderella never found the courage to escape and continued to suffer at the hands of her mother and sisters.

(Elsa approaches the city gates and finds a group of soldiers, vividly recounting her experience with Cinderella) Thank you, young lady, for entertaining us and driving away our boredom. If you've finished, you can leave now. We've enjoyed the show, hahahahaha.

(Elsa did not expect the soldiers to be unreliable, so she went to the church and sincerely shared her family misfortunes with the priest) Your mother and sister are guilty of terrible crimes, Elsa, you are right and just, the Lord is pleased with you. Here is a holy scripture for you, the way to salvation is within. Lastly, please donate to the Lord. Elsa felt a chill of disgust, donated a small sum, and left. No one seemed willing to help her, and she was once again lost in confusion.

content.content: (Elsa really wanted to just give up and openly confront her mother and sister, but she held back her impulse) I want to run away far with Cinderella, but we have to be smart about it. We need to escape when mother, father, and sister don't notice. I have to secretly find Cinderella to discuss the detailed plan.
(Eyes filled with anger) I just want to threaten them with a knife to their throats to make them apologize for their actions.
The situation is critical and I can't manage much, I'll just go home and grab Cinderella to run. We are young and can run fast, they shouldn't be able to catch us.
I'll go back and see if just running away is feasible. If not, I'll use Cinderella as a shield, saying she told me to do so.

question: #question# How can Elsa demonstrate that she can consciously control her impulsiveness?

content.content: After calming down a bit, she sighed:
(Feeling anxious inside but forcing herself to stay composed):
I'm still very scared, what should I do, do I really have to make this decision? I'm a bit cowardly.

(Elsa was left with no choice. She thought that since she couldn't change things, she might as well try to endure it bravely. She had been enduring it for so long anyway and had slowly started to adapt.) Let’s go home first. I am already able to accept the change in how my mother and sister treat me.

question: #question# How can Elsa quickly demonstrate adaptability to the changes around her or from others?

content.content: I am my mother’s own daughter, how can she bear to treat me this way? I can't accept it!
I really can't take it anymore. What kind of life am I living every day? It's too miserable.
The whole family treats me like this, I am really on the verge of breaking down. I feel like I can’t hold on anymore.

dialog.content: (With tears in her eyes after hearing Elsa's detailed plan for escaping with their savings) I'm in. Let's go pack our things now and leave tonight if we get the chance!

At night, while everyone was asleep, Elsa and Cinderella boarded a train to escape their tormented home. Their mother and the others did not search for them, and far away, Elsa and Cinderella started leading normal and stable lives.
Tamani
(Aisha smiled vacantly, saying as she walked toward the laundry room) Okay, got it.

From that point on, Aisha became like a walking corpse, devoid of a soul, and Cinderella no longer asked questions. The two of them just lived in the household, subject to orders and treated like slaves, doing all the work fit for servants.

(At the dinner table) Cinderella, is it your turn to eat yet? Did you finish cleaning before you sat down to eat? Hasn't anyone ever taught you to finish your work before thinking about something else? Check and finish your work first. (Muttering) Can't even do a servant's job right.
(I can't let Cinderella be insulted here, so I have to pretend I'm on my sister's side) Cinderella, don't eat yet. Go wash my clothes first.

(While Elsa secretly hides some food) There will be a grand ball lasting three days in the capital next week, and it's time for you three sisters to find suitors, so you should all attend. I'm going out tomorrow to get each of you something needed for the ball. What would you like?
Let me go first! I want a gold lace tiara!
I haven't decided yet. What about you, Cinderella?
(Softly) We already have everything for the ball that Mother left behind, no need to buy more. I just want Father to pick a five-colored mushroom from the forest outside the city.

content.content: (What should I choose, this is so hard, but Dad said to get something for each of us. If I don't choose, won't it be disrespectful to him? I better listen to Dad and choose something quickly) Dad, my previous pair of high heels are rubbing my feet a bit. I'd like to replace them, so how about a pair of glass slippers.

question: #question# How can Elsa demonstrate that she takes her father's wishes into consideration when doing things?

content.content: (Oh, Dad insists that everyone has to choose something. What if I really can't choose? Can I not choose and let him pick one directly? What to do? What to do? I really can't think of anything. Can one of you help me? Or can Dad just pick one for me? Dad should know our preferences quite well.
(Expressionless) I don't want anything. I don't like any of it. (Frowning) What's so important about a ball? I can't even be bothered to dress up or attend.

(Torn inside) Dad, I have decision paralysis and can't choose anything. I've thought about it, and I already have what I need. The things I don't have are things our family can't afford. So what should I choose? I know, Dad, you really want to help us find marriage prospects, so you think this ball is important. But I really can't choose. If you really want to buy something, just pick one for me. It's not like I'm disrespecting you; I'm trying to save you money.
(Dad has to be away for a few days again; it's exhausting and hard on him) I don't really want anything special. I just want Dad to come home safe and sound.

question: #question# What could Elsa say to make her dad feel more comforted and reassured?

content.content: Dad, how can you only bring back one thing? How can I choose like this? I want more than one thing.
Buy me jewelry, but my share has to be the most, more than what the whole family gets combined.
Honestly, Dad, your taste leaves something to be desired. Can you really choose something good if I tell you what I want? I'm really worried.

dialog.content: (lost in thought for a moment) Alright, I have noted everything down. (A few days later, the father returns home) Here are the gifts you wanted. This is for Anna, this is for Cinderella, and this is (pauses for a few seconds) for Elsa. Elsa, come here. (with a somewhat serious expression, gives Elsa her gift in the corner) Elsa, this is the gift you wanted, but make sure Cinderella doesn't see these glass slippers.
Huh?! Why, Father? What's wrong with the glass slippers?
It's nothing. Just remember what I said, and don't concern yourself with anything else.

(Soon, the day of the ball arrives, and mother and sister are already prepared. Only Elsa is still getting ready. At this time, Cinderella walks into the room, looking distressed) I also want to go to the ball, but I’m one ticket short. Mother, can you help me?

(gives Cinderella a disdainful look from head to toe, then mercilessly mocks her) You want to go too? Well, that’s fine. If you finish the chores at home, you can go. (With that, Tetani spills a bowl of beans into the stove) Oh dear, I was so careless. Cinderella, as long as you pick all the beans out of the ashes, you can go to the ball. After all, you have to do your job properly before you can go.
(Cinderella crouches by the stove, picking beans with tears in her eyes) Okay, Mother, I’ll do it right away. You can go ahead and do your thing.

content.content: (Although Elsa really wants to help Cinderella, she calmly analyzes the situation. No matter what, Mother won't let Cinderella go to the ball. Defying Mother will only anger her more. The best choice now is to let Cinderella quietly pick the beans. If she doesn't anger Mother, maybe she'll be in a good mood after returning from the ball and will let Cinderella go tomorrow) Oh well, I'll just leave it be. I need to quickly check what else isn't ready; the ball is about to start. Let’s hurry up and get ready to leave.

question: #question# How can Elsa demonstrate that she understands the situation and applies new information?

content.content: (frantically making a scene to divert her mother's attention) Oh no, where are my false eyelashes? Where did I put them, Mother?
Alright, everyone stop talking. Constant chatter is so annoying; my ears are developing calluses.
(mockingly) Stop bullying Cinderella. She can't go to the ball anyway, and that's pitiful enough.

(Too angry, too excessive. No, I have to hold it in, I can't shout at her. If I publicly confront Mother, it'll be even harder for Cinderella later) Oh, I think my period just started. It hurts so much, I can't go to the ball, my stomach hurts too much. Mom, you and sister go ahead; I need to lie down for a bit because it's really painful.

question: #question# How does Elsa regulate some impulsive behaviors and adapt to the situation?

content.content: (suddenly flips the table in front of her) Mother, what are you doing? This is too much. If these beans fall into the stove, won't they turn to ash immediately? Why not cut off a lock of your hair and throw it in for Cinderella to pick? Wouldn't that satisfy you even more? What did Cinderella do wrong? Could you please stop bullying her?

Cinderella, there's a sieve in the warehouse. Use that to sift the beans out immediately. Or just take a shovel and scoop everything out of the stove. Turn off the stove, and everyone freezes together tonight.

(looks at her sister) Sister, you don't have any issues with this? You think this is alright? Fine, since that's the case, I really have nothing to say to the two of you. Maybe we just aren't the same kind of people, we have different values, and there's no helping that. Even though we share the same blood, there's no spiritual connection. I'm really disappointed in you.

dialog.content: (Soon, the ball will begin, and everyone sees Cinderella at the door. Elsa goes to check) Elsa, could you do me a favor? I have a pair of beautiful glass slippers, but their color doesn't quite match me. They would look great on you. Can we swap?

content.content: (Elsa closely observes that Cinderella has become much more beautiful. She's changed into a lovely dress and put on exquisite makeup. It seems Cinderella genuinely wants to attend the ball. Indeed, the color of the glass slippers doesn't quite match. Elsa thinks that swapping shoes isn't a big deal.) Sure, let's swap.
But you're dressed so plain and it doesn't really match my shoes either. I feel like it makes no difference whether we swap or not. I prefer my own shoes, let's not swap.
(Rolls eyes) I didn't come here to swap stuff with you. My mother told me to chase you away. Don't embarrass our family.
My shoes are so beautiful, everyone wants them. I won't swap with anyone; I want to keep my perfect look!

question: #question# How can Elsa demonstrate her meticulous skills?

content.content: (Unconcerned) Cinderella, you're too particular! Does it really matter if it matches? It's good enough to have them. (Slight frown, glancing over Cinderella's outfit, talking to herself) Cinderella does look very pretty, but her shoes and dress don't quite match. Yet, the details aren't that important, are they? After all, her overall appearance is striking; no one will just focus on her shoes. Perhaps I shouldn't dwell on such small matters, as long as she's happy. There are so many people at the ball; no one will notice the shoes.

(Shaking head) No way, your glass slippers aren't as nice as mine. I won't swap with you. The color might not be perfect, but overall, it doesn't make much difference, right? Shoes not matching the dress color? Well, maybe it’s a bit of a problem, but the lighting at the ball should cover these details. It shouldn't attract much attention. There's probably no need to waste time swapping shoes for this minor issue; heading straight to the ball is more important, as no one will care about such tiny details.
Cinderella, why are you here? Did you finish picking out all the beans from the furnace before running out here, wanting to swap shoes with me? Mother will be angry if she finds out.
(As Elsa arrives, she hears the guard at the door saying, 'Anyone left outside? Hurry, the door's closing soon.') Oh, sorry, I need to rush to the ball now. I don't have time to swap shoes with you.

question: #question# How can Elsa demonstrate her time management skills effectively?

content.content: I never intended to swap with you. I'm out of time; you'll have to think of something else. I need to hurry inside.

(Hesitant) Oh, what should I do? There's not much time left. Can I still swap shoes in time? Ah, the ball is starting soon, but these shoes are really uncomfortable. If I just go like this, it might be painful to walk during the ball. I should change shoes, although time is a bit tight. If I walk quickly, I should still make it. The ball might not start right away, and it’s just the usual introductions at first anyway; arriving a little late wouldn't be too bad.
No time left. Cinderella, just take my shoes and go. I'm not going to the ball anymore.

dialog.content: (Cinderella smiles, very happy) Oh, thank you so much!

(The next day, joyful news came from the capital. Last night at the ball, the prince fell in love at first sight with a young lady, who turned out to be Cinderella, and he made her a princess. The news has already reached home) Oh my, this is unbelievable! Cinderella actually became a princess!

(The mother and sister are shocked and immediately start to worry) Mother, what should we do? Do you think Cinderella will come back for revenge? She's a princess now; she wouldn't seek revenge on us, right?

Cinderella became a princess. To repay Elsa, Cinderella brought her back to the capital, and they became good friends. Cinderella provided Elsa with a life without worries. As for her stepmother and sister, Cinderella neither took revenge nor offered them charity, and they continued to live a simple life.
(Just as Elsa was about to turn and leave, Cinderella suddenly grabbed her from behind) If I can't go in, neither can you!

(Elsa was pulled down to the ground, utterly shocked at Cinderella’s actions) Cinderella, I can't believe you would do this, especially after I've secretly been helping you at home. How could you treat me like this?
(Cinderella, overwhelmed with emotion, started recounting her hardships and helplessness and, amid her explanation, took out a colorful mushroom and ate it) I'm sorry, Elsa.

Cinderella poisoned herself. After the ball, Elsa told her mother about the incident. Her mother scolded Cinderella harshly. Life returned to normal afterward, but Elsa always regretted this event, and three years later, she succumbed to depression.

(Rolling her eyes repeatedly) You child, why didn't you say anything beforehand? Such an important opportunity, and you just decide not to go. Fine, don't regret it later. Anna, let's go, we'll leave her be.
Cinderella, I'm not feeling well, so I'm not going. I'll go back to my room to rest for a while.
(Sobbing) Okay, take care of yourself and call me if you need anything.

(Aisha sees Cinderella looking so pitiful and sincerely hopes she can showcase her beauty at the ball. She notices that Cinderella's shoes don't quite match her dress, so she goes against her father's advice and places her own glass slippers under the tree in the courtyard where Cinderella goes almost every day, then returns to her room) Not going is also good, I'll return to my warm bed and sleep soundly!

(After tidying up, Cinderella went to the familiar courtyard) Eh, aren't these the glass slippers? Thank you, Aisha, I know you're helping me. I'll go to the ball and come right back; I'll return the shoes to their original spot later.

content.content: (In the early morning, while everyone is asleep, Aisha decides to check the courtyard and notices dirt on the bottom of the glass slippers) It seems Cinderella has already worn the glass slippers to the ball, but the ball lasts for three days. Since I've helped Cinderella once, I should see it through to the end. For the next two days, I'll continue secretly placing the shoes for Cinderella. This will be our little secret.

question: #question# How can Aisha demonstrate her determination and persistence?

content.content: (Hesitant) If I continue helping Cinderella secretly, mother is likely to find out. She already disapproves of me not going to the ball. If she finds out about this, our household will be in chaos. Sigh. But Cinderella must have realized it was me who secretly placed the shoes under the tree yesterday. If I don't help her, will she feel disappointed?

Yesterday, I already helped Cinderella attend the ball once. Without me, she might not have been able to attend at all. But the ball goes on for three days. Should I really not go even once? Maybe we can both take turns attending the ball. I think Cinderella wouldn't mind. Perhaps I'll go to the ball today.

(Sighs deeply) The glass slippers are so precious, and now the soles are all muddy. I haven't even worn them once. Why didn't Cinderella clean the soles a bit before returning them? I'm starting to regret lending the shoes to her (looks troubled).

(In the early morning, Aisha decides to check the courtyard while everyone is asleep and finds dirt on the bottom of the glass slippers) It seems Cinderella has already worn the glass slippers to the ball, but the ball lasts for three days. Since I've already helped Cinderella go once, I'll also go and experience it today.

question: #question# How can Aisha illustrate her own thoughts and personal goals while helping others?

content.content: (In the early morning, Aisha decides to check the courtyard while everyone is asleep and finds dirt on the bottom of the glass slippers) It seems Cinderella has already worn the glass slippers to the ball, but the ball lasts for three days. Ah, continue helping others thoroughly, and help Cinderella fulfill her wish.

(In the early morning, Aisha decides to check the courtyard while everyone is asleep and finds dirt on the bottom of the glass slippers) It seems Cinderella has already worn the glass slippers to the ball, but the ball lasts for three days. (Conflicted) What should I do? I want to go to the ball myself, but I also really want to help Cinderella.

(In the early morning, Aisha decides to check the courtyard while everyone is asleep and finds dirt on the bottom of the glass slippers) It seems Cinderella has already worn the glass slippers to the ball, but the ball lasts for three days. Well, maybe I'll leave them for one more day and then discuss with Cinderella about letting me go on the last day.

dialog.content: (The next day, Elsa continued to deceive her mother using the excuse of a stomachache) Elsa is such a fool! A rare chance to go to the capital to attend the ball and broaden her horizons, yet she never appreciates these opportunities.

(Once her mother and sister left, Elsa returned the glass slipper to its place from the day before, and just like the first day, it worked. Until the last day of the ball, Elsa tried to retrieve the slipper at dawn, only to find one was missing) Huh?! What happened? Why is there only one of my glass slippers left? Never mind, it's late, I'll deal with it in the morning.

(The next morning, explosive news from the capital said that the prince had fallen in love with a mysterious lady at the ball. The only clue to finding her was the glass slipper she lost. Soldiers were going door-to-door trying on the slipper, and the prince would marry whichever girl it fit. Just as Elsa was shocked and about to question Cinderella, the door was kicked open, and a group of soldiers rushed in, with their leader holding a glass slipper identical to Elsa’s, yelling) All women in the house, come try on the slipper!

content.content: (Even though my foot would surely fit, they are definitely looking for Cinderella. I never went to the ball anyway, so now is the perfect opportunity to help Cinderella escape from this household. I must let her try the slipper first.) I'm really sorry, I have athlete's foot, I need to wash my feet first. Let Cinderella and my sister try it first.

question: #question# What should Elsa do to align with her values and pursuits?

content.content: (Her heart racing, extremely excited) My God, what a golden opportunity! If I try on the slipper and it fits, I can become the princess. This isn’t just a pair of shoes—it’s a chance to change my fate. I must seize it and become the one and only princess.
(Very angry at the soldiers' rude behavior) If you have something to say, say it, why kick down the door? Is this breaking and entering? I'm going to sue you!

(Elsa immediately locked Cinderella in a room and brought out her other shoe) It’s me! It’s me! I can fit it—I just happened to lose one yesterday. I'll warn you, don't say anything about it, or you know what my mother might do. I've helped you once before, so help me this time.

(Elsa calmly thinks it over. She can't let her mother discover Cinderella went to the ball, or her mother will definitely not spare Cinderella. If Elsa tries on the slipper first and becomes the princess, it would be easier to help Cinderella escape from this house.) Me, me, me, I'll try it first! (Elsa rushed forward, grabbing the glass slipper and successfully putting it on in front of everyone) These shoes are indeed mine. I did go to the ball, right Mom?

question: #question# How can Elsa demonstrate she has carefully considered her decision?

content.content: I don’t care anymore, who wouldn't want to be a princess? Being a princess is not just a symbol—it’s a windfall opportunity I must seize. Who wouldn’t want to own a magnificent palace, exquisite clothes, and countless servants? Who wouldn’t want to be the center of attention at a ball, enjoying the privileges and honors exclusive to royalty?

(Groggy) So annoying, all this noise, who barged into the house? (Finishes with a big yawn) Whatever, it doesn’t matter who. Right now, the most important thing for me is to return to my warm bed and continue my beautiful dream. I’ll ignore those pesky sounds for now—I’m too sleepy. I have to go back for a nap.

Seriously, who doesn't want to fly up and become a phoenix? But being a phoenix isn't that easy—I don’t want to try. Besides, I guess they're looking for Cinderella since I haven’t been to the ball, right? Forced fruit isn’t sweet, but if Cinderella is found, she can escape too. (Smiles contentedly)

dialog.content: (Cinderella tried on the glass slipper, and it fit perfectly) Wait a minute, (Anna exclaimed loudly), hold on, wasn’t this pair of glass slippers bought for our second sister by Father? Even though Father secretly pulled her aside to give her the gift, I saw it. Well, Cinderella, did you actually steal it?? We provided for you, and now you turn out to be a thief. (With that said, all eyes turned towards Elsa, and the tension in the room became unbearable under her sister's accusations and their mother's piercing gaze.)

content.content: (Although Elsa really didn't want to admit it, she had always been an honest child, adhering to moral integrity, and couldn't lie under her mother's questioning) Ah yes, these shoes are indeed mine.

question: #question# What should Elsa do to reflect her consistent honesty and trustworthiness to her family?

content.content: (Playing dumb) Are they mine? I can't remember. Did I ever ask Father to buy them?
These aren't my glass slippers, maybe we just have similar ones.
Oh, since Cinderella can wear the glass slipper, then it's not mine. They just look similar, and besides, her feet are so dirty, why would I let her wear my shoes?

(Elsa almost confessed honestly, but she remembered she wanted to help Cinderella, so she took a deep breath and pretended to be calm) This isn’t my shoe. I haven’t been to the ball in days, I’ve been feeling unwell, resting at home, you must be mistaken, my dance shoes are still with me. Although dad did give me a pair of glass slippers, I accidentally dropped them into the river when I went to play there a couple of days ago, and I was upset about it for a while.

question: #question# How can Elsa demonstrate that she can effectively manage her feelings of stress in tense situations?

content.content: (Elsa couldn't help but cry) What? I don’t know, I know nothing about it. These aren’t mine, I don’t have such shoes (with a hesitant expression), Sis, you must have seen wrong, don’t mislead Mom.

(Sighs, somewhat helplessly) Okay, you say these shoes are mine, but I really don’t remember. Things have been so hectic lately, I really haven’t had the mind for these little things. Maybe you should check again, perhaps they really aren’t mine?
(Slightly frowning, with a hesitant tone):

dialog.content: (The mother is extremely angry, questioning Elsa) Elsa, explain why your crystal shoe is with Cinderella?
Huh? I...
(Turns to Cinderella) And you, take off Elsa’s crystal shoe immediately! Those shoes are not yours at all; you didn't even attend the ball.

content.content: (Elsa is at a loss for what to do, but she trusts that having helped Cinderella for so long, being like sisters, Cinderella will definitely speak up for her. So she silently looks at Cinderella) Cinderella, what do you say?

question: #question# What could Elsa do to show she trusts that Cinderella will help her?

content.content: Mom, if she can wear them, she definitely won't admit she didn't go.
(Nervous and scared) What do I do? What do I do? Because Mom and Sister bully her, she definitely won't like me or help me.
(Afraid of being misunderstood, Elsa runs away, saying while running) I don't know what's going on either, don't follow me.

(Elsa is very angry, completely disappointed in her mother and sister. This time she's determined to protect Cinderella. She shouts) I can't believe even at this point, Mom and Sister still plan to make Cinderella suffer. Stop bullying Cinderella! I'm really fed up with being oppressed by you like this.
(Fearful yet clear-minded) In this situation, I better not continue helping Cinderella, otherwise, Mom won't let me go.
(Turns to Cinderella) Say something, Cinderella, tell everyone the whole story, don't leave me to take the blame.
(To save herself, Elsa has no choice but to wrong Cinderella) Yes, Cinderella, where did you get the shoes? You actually stole them from me.

question: #question# What could Elsa do to show she has a strong sense of responsibility and actively protects Cinderella?

content.content: (With a tremor in her voice, she clenches her teeth and says) I've really had enough! Mom and Sister have always treated Cinderella this way, and I really don't want to endure it anymore. But what can I do? They won't listen to me at all; my words mean nothing to them. Maybe I should find an opportunity to leave this house, then think of a way to help Cinderella... This way I won’t have to constantly fight against them, this life is suffocating.

I'm really fed up with all this, why do Mom and Sister always target Cinderella? What they're doing is really too much, but... if I stand up now, might they retaliate against me? If they become even worse, then I can't protect Cinderella either. Maybe I should be cautious and not let them know I'm planning to help Cinderella. I'll support her quietly so she can find a chance to escape, and this way, she can finally rid herself of this nightmare.

(Sighs, expressing helplessness) I've long been disgusted with Mom and Sister's attitude towards Cinderella, but in the current situation, I really don't know how to resolve it. They always team up to bully Cinderella, and I am powerless to change it all by myself. Maybe I should wait for a better opportunity to stand up for Cinderella. Going against them now might not only fail to help Cinderella but also drag me into it. I'll decide what to do when things calm down a bit.

dialog.content: (Everyone looked at Cinderella again. She was terrified and at a loss, clinging to the nearby officer and urgently saying) I'm the girl you're looking for, please take me to see the prince now!

(The officer, seeing this, wanted to resolve things swiftly, and upon giving a command, ignored the mother's cries and escorted Cinderella away) Miss, this way, please~ Please come with us to the capital to meet the prince.

(From then on, Elsa was ostracized at home, quickly falling into the position Cinderella once held. As time passed, overwhelmed by suffering, Elsa secretly wrote a letter to Cinderella, beseeching her to help in the matter of the glass slipper. But within a few days, a group of soldiers broke into her home and took Elsa away to prison. After several days in the cell, Cinderella finally came to see Elsa) Cinderella, no, my lady, what is happening, please help me.

(Cinderella, now dressed in a lavish gown, with not a speck of dust on her, looked nothing like the Cinderella she once was. Upon seeing Elsa, she lowered her head and pretended to wipe her tears before sincerely apologizing to Elsa, then said) Elsa, you know the prince must never find out the secret of the glass slipper, so I hope you will sacrifice yourself for me. (Cinderella tossed a multicolored mushroom at Elsa's feet, giving her a meaningful look) Elsa, it's up to you to decide what to do, my intentions are clear. (Having said that, she turned and left without looking back)

content.content: (Initially startled, Elsa then thought, Cinderella isn't really that cruel, so she calmed down. She figured it must be just to scare her, and as long as she declared she would keep the secret, Cinderella would help her, there had to be a way. So she thought of calling someone to send a message to Cinderella) Is anyone there? Hello? Anyone?

question: #question# How can Elsa show she remains optimistic in difficult situations?

content.content: (Regretfully) Oh my, she's trying to poison me with this mushroom, I'm doomed. Could this be just an act of hers? I hope she can still be as kind as before, but I'm not sure if she's still the same person now. Maybe I should test her reaction first, then decide whether to assure her I'll keep her secret. Even though I want to believe she wouldn't harm me, the situation is just too complicated, I can't be entirely optimistic.

Cinderella does look daunting, but surely she's not the type to harm others, right? I hope so... But what if she really has changed? Perhaps this experience has made her cold and ruthless, I'm not entirely confident she'll help me. If I misjudge her and tell her I'll keep the secret, it might be completely ineffective. I should try, but also be prepared for the worst, because I can't solely rely on her.

(Despondently) Well, might as well eat it, it seems my death is inevitable anyway. I can't believe Cinderella would do such a thing... But still, I think she's not the type to harm others. Maybe this is her way of scaring me, but I'm not 100% sure. If I tell her I'll keep her secret, will she really believe me? Or will she suspect I have ulterior motives? Even though I hope she'll help me, I have to consider what to do if she doesn't. I can't depend entirely on her, I've got to have a backup plan.

(Elsa, disheartened, thought long and hard. Now that Cinderella is a princess, she could dispose of Elsa effortlessly, and Elsa couldn't resist at all, so why not die gracefully) Eating the multicolored mushroom doesn't sound too bad. Sigh, at least it’s a release.

question: #question# How can Elsa demonstrate she has made a well-considered decision?

content.content: I refuse to eat it; there are laws in this world, she can't kill me for no reason.
(Shouting in fear) What do I do, what do I do, can someone save me, help, someone help me!
(Collapsing) Cinderella, you little tyrant! I'm going to tell the whole world the secret, let me out!

dialog.content: (Elsa calls out loudly from her cell, but no one responds. Two days later, Elsa reunites with her mother and sister in the square of the capital.) Huh? Mother, sister...
(At this moment, all three of them are tied up, surrounded by a countless crowd. Anna looks at Elsa with only a sigh.) Sigh~

Under countless disdainful gazes, the mother and daughters were executed by hanging. To ensure her inspiring tale and the crimes of her stepmother and sister were remembered, Cinderella had her story written down and it has been passed down ever since.
(After Elsa was poisoned to death, the watchful soldier promptly informed Cinderella) Princess, that young lady has been poisoned to death.
(As if she expected it) Got it, go and capture the remaining two from her family.

Elsa willingly took poison and died. After her death, Cinderella praised Elsa as a great sister who quietly protected her in a perverse family, ultimately sacrificing herself. Consequently, Cinderella punished her mother and sister by executing them through hanging.

(As Elsa loses her sanity during the heated argument and loses control of her emotions, she picks up a pair of scissors nearby and violently stabs her own foot, immediately resulting in a bloody mess) (Cinderella rushes to Elsa and snatches the scissors from her hand) Elsa, don't do this! Calm down, put down the scissors. I'll take care of it. You just rest for a while.
(With her mind blank) I don't even know what I'm doing.

(Under everyone's gaze, Cinderella takes off the glass slipper and returns it to the officer) I'm sorry, I never attended the ball; I just happened to fit into the slipper, so I'm not the girl the prince is looking for.
(Seeing this, the officer no longer wishes to stay and leaves with the glass slipper. Cinderella quickly disinfects and bandages Elsa's wound) Thank you, Cinderella!

From then on, Elsa's mother and sister ignored her, and the bullying toward Cinderella became even worse. After Elsa completely fell out with her mother, she had no reservations and became good friends with Cinderella. Two years later, after saving enough money, the two left this home and went to a distant city, where they opened a flower shop together and lived a happy life.
(After a brief argument, Elsa still refused to admit) Alright, we won't bother you anymore. Miss Cinderella, please come with us to meet the prince. Once you meet him, everything will be clear.

(A few days later, Cinderella became the king's princess. Her mother and sister were constantly worried that Cinderella would come back to take revenge on them, and they took out these negative emotions on Elsa. Soon, Elsa replaced Cinderella's original position) Elsa, you're not allowed to eat until you've washed all our clothes. You're the biggest fool in the family. If it weren't for you, we would all be living the high life in the capital now.

One day, Elsa received a secret letter from Cinderella. In it, Cinderella thanked Elsa for her long-term help and the glass slippers. In return, she was willing to offer Elsa wealth and prosperity for life. The only condition Elsa had to agree to was to leave the capital and keep the secret of the glass slippers until her death. Elsa agreed, but her life felt like a heavy burden, crushing her spirit.

(Knowing this is a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity, Temannie immediately steps forward with a delighted expression to curry favor with the officer) Yes, that's right, we've all been attending the balls together these past few days, and yesterday I accidentally lost this shoe.

And so, Elsa was taken away by the soldiers. When she met the prince, he instantly recognized that Elsa was not the young lady he was looking for, but constrained by royal protocol, the prince married Elsa anyway. As a result, her mother and sister also enjoyed a life of luxury and wealth, while Cinderella disappeared from that day onwards, her fate unknown.

(The next day, Elsa dressed up carefully and went to the ball with her mother, full of anticipation.) These glass slippers are so beautiful, wearing them to the ball is truly delightful. The ball in this capital city is indeed extraordinary; the food is so rich and everything is so delicious. Coming here was totally worth it, so fun and so tasty, I’m having such a great time!

(After the ball ended, the group happily returned home, only to find someone lying in a pool of blood under a tree in the courtyard. Anna was the first to check.) Oh my God, is this Cinderella? She's covered in blood. (She began to cry uncontrollably) Mom, Dad, I'm scared, she looks like she's dead, what should we do?

Later, an investigation revealed that Cinderella had stayed home the next day because she had no pretty high heels to wear. Unfortunately, a gang of thieves broke into the mansion when there were few people around, and a conflict ensued with the remaining Cinderella. Cinderella tragically died. Elsa felt if she'd supported Cinderella for just one more day, the tragedy might have been avoided. She spent the rest of her life full of guilt, which was very unfortunate.
(fondly pats Elsa's head) Elsa has grown up. Alright, I remember everything you guys wanted.

(A few days later, the father returned with gifts for the sister and Cinderella, but staying true to his word, he didn't buy anything for Elsa) Dad, you're back. Wow. These are gifts for my sister and Cinderella, right? They look really nice.

(proudly wearing a beautiful gold tiara) Elsa, in our country, every ball hosted by the royal aristocracy requires wearing a luxurious accessory as a ticket to attend. You didn't ask for anything, and you have nothing, and with you being so busy with work lately, are you planning to go to the ball or not?

content.content: (Elsa still wants to go to the ball. She thinks her mother should have plenty of luxurious accessories, and as her daughter wanting to use one as a ticket, her mother surely wouldn't object. Elsa is quite confident in her relationship with her mother) I've got it, I'll ask Mom for help.

question: #question# How can Elsa demonstrate her unwavering confidence in her relationship with her mother?

content.content: Who can I ask for help? Mom is too strict; I'm afraid to ask her for help.
Mom prefers my older sister, them going to the ball together would be enough; she probably doesn't want to take me.
I had a little argument with Mom before while defending Cinderella, she's probably really annoyed with me now.
(These past few days, I've been working continuously, and the ball is on the weekend. Maybe I should just stay home and recharge) Forget it, I've been exhausted lately, I won't go to the ball.

question: #question# How can Elsa maintain her energy between continuous work and the weekend ball?

content.content: That's amusing, how could a young person be bothered by this ball? I've got energy to spare, can't even use it all up.
Enjoyment is what's most important. I'm going to the ball, and work can wait. To hell with work, it tires a person out.
(hesitating and conflicted) Should I go or not? I'll draw lots, leave it to luck and fate.

dialog.content: (Elsa, trying to please, crawls to her mother’s knee. Her mother pats Elsa’s head) Alright, I know you well enough; you want to borrow some jewelry, right? Alright, I agree. Now hurry back to bed.
(The next day, her mother brings a mysterious box with crystal shoes to Elsa and asks her to try them on) Huh? They’re too small, I can’t fit into them.

(Seeing this, her mother puts the crystal shoes away, removes a pair of earrings that Elsa’s biological father had given her, and hands them to Elsa) These shoes were a gift from your father, if they don’t fit, I can lend you these earrings instead, but only for three days.

content.content: (Slightly troubled) Maybe not. I’ve never really liked formal events since I was a child, and now I might just be curious, but once there, I’ll probably feel uncomfortable again. So, Mom, I think I don’t want to go.

question: #question#How can Elsa use her past experiences to help decide whether to attend the party?

content.content: (After hesitating, with a hint of conflict in her voice) I don’t know if I should go... Actually, I’m not really interested in such occasions, but maybe a change of scenery isn’t a bad idea? Although I haven’t liked formal settings since I was young, perhaps I could try to adapt? Plus, everyone says the ball is fun; maybe I should give myself more chances? But if I feel uneasy once I’m there, I wouldn’t know what to do... Maybe I should just go and see how it turns out.

(With a faint, resigned smile) Ah, frankly, I’m not sure if I really want to go. I didn’t like formal settings when I was younger, but now that I’m grown up, I should be different, right? After all, I can’t live based on childhood feelings; I need to learn to adapt to new environments. Maybe I should challenge myself; even if it’s uncomfortable, I should try to adapt. I might find that I’ve actually grown to like these events more.

Although the ball seems intriguing, I’ve never liked such formal settings. But, would I miss something important if I don’t go? Maybe I’m overthinking, everyone seems to enjoy themselves, why not try to enjoy it too? Perhaps I should stop pondering so much and just attend, not letting my feelings restrict me. If I feel uncomfortable when I get there, I can just leave; it’s not a big deal. I want to challenge myself to engage in high-end settings that don’t suit me.

(Although Elsa finds these earrings quite ugly, she believes she can use her knack for organizing to dress up beautifully with other accessories and clothes) Alright, I’ll tidy myself up and wear the earrings to the ball.

question: #question#How can Elsa demonstrate her ability to organize her belongings and plan her outfits well?

content.content: (Frowns at the earrings, hesitates a bit, and softly comments) Hmm, these earrings... They’re not quite my style, but if I tie my hair up and match it with that white gown, it might work. Though the dress might need some tweaking... Or I could try pairing it with another dress, hmm, I’ll go see what I can find, if it doesn’t work, I might have to choose other accessories.

Is just this pair of earrings enough? (After thinking for a while, she mutters to herself) These earrings might not be to my taste, but maybe I can find a way to make them look better. I’ll first change into that purple long dress and pair it with the glittery necklace, they should complement each other, right? But it might be too flashy... Maybe I should try something else, or does the blue shawl fit better? Wait, what time does the ball start? Am I already late? Maybe time is running out, and I’ll just have to quickly pick some things to wear, everything’s such a mess and I can’t find anything.

(Forces a smile, tone light with a hint of dissatisfaction) Mom, these earrings... hmm, they’re indeed a bit unique and aren’t something I’d usually wear. But no worries, I’ll try to match them, even though the colors are a bit out of place, maybe I can find an outfit to go with them. Honestly, though, it would be nice if there were more options matching my style next time.

dialog.content: (Elsa didn't attend the ball; she couldn't sleep that night and went to the yard to admire the moon, where she encountered Cinderella crying secretly) What brings you here? (Cinderella hurriedly tried to hide her tears and glared at Elsa) Sorry to disturb your walk. I'll go somewhere else. I'm just an unlucky servant and don't want to be a nuisance.
(Sighing deeply, she lost even the mood to watch the stars and the moon) Ah, I guess I'll just go back to sleep.

The ball ended, and the group happily returned home, but upon reaching the yard, they discovered Cinderella collapsed under a tree, with a partially eaten colorful mushroom in her hand. She was already dead. Soon after, a group of soldiers received a report and arrested her father for murder, imprisoning him. The remaining mother and daughters struggled to survive without means of livelihood for the rest of their lives.

(At night, Elsa tidied up and waited for her mother and sister to get ready to leave, but suddenly heard her sister scream and hurried over) Elsa, have you seen your sister’s golden crown? Your sister’s golden crown is missing; it must have been stolen by someone.
(Her sister suddenly seemed to recall something and rushed into Cinderella’s room) I saw her sneaking around my door today—it must have been her who stole my golden crown!

(Anna frantically searched Cinderella’s room and, after a while, indeed found Anna’s golden crown in a secret compartment of a cabinet. Her sister furiously scolded Cinderella, and Elsa was also deeply shocked) Cinderella, I can’t believe you’d do something like this. You’ve betrayed my trust.

Since that incident, Elsa decided not to help Cinderella anymore. She realized Cinderella was not the innocent victim she appeared to be, and she was retaliating against her sister and mother. After that, Elsa turned a blind eye to her mother and sister’s bullying of Cinderella. She didn’t want to side with anyone anymore.

(Softly crying under a tree planted by her mother before she passed away) Mom, I miss you so much. If only you were still here with me. (Elsa is having a bit of insomnia at night and wants to go to the yard to relax by looking at the moon. However, as soon as she steps into the yard, she finds Cinderella softly crying under the tree her mother had planted. Elsa decides to approach and accompany her and clears her throat softly to signal her presence) Cinderella, are you okay?
(Clears her throat gently) Cinderella, are you alright? What's wrong? Are you feeling unwell?
(Cinderella instantly lifts her head upon hearing a voice and slightly relaxes when she sees it's Elsa) Oh, it's you. My apologies for being upset. I'm fine.

content.content: (She looks so pitiful, I should stay and chat with her a bit longer) Cinderella, just look at how round and bright the moon is tonight. Isn't it beautiful?

question: #question# How should Elsa continue the conversation with Cinderella when she's upset?

content.content: (Frowning) I'm too tongue-tied, seeing you like this I'm not sure what to say...
Why are you crying? It seems a bit awkward, should I step aside?
Cinderella, I'm still your sister, aren't I? Why can't you talk nicely to me? Otherwise, I'll tell Mom when she's back.

(Looking around, making sure neither Mom nor Sister is around) Cinderella, I'm sorry for everything that happened before, I really am. I was just putting on an act, but I'm truly sorry. I feel very guilty inside; I'm a bit cowardly and lack the courage to stand up to them.

question: #question# How can Elsa make Cinderella understand her true feelings?

content.content: (Her mind goes blank) Cinderella, please don't cry. I'm at a loss.
(Caught in a dilemma) I can't decide whether to stay or go, what should I do?
I know you're very sad. Sigh, it seems like I can't really help you. I feel helpless...

dialog.content: (Cinderella and Elsa are having a great time chatting, and gradually Cinderella starts smiling) Elsa, thank you for today. It's getting late, you should head back and rest. They'll be back from the ball soon, and if they see us talking and laughing together, it might not be good for you.
(Elsa is also very happy) Okay, you should get some rest early too.

(After the ball, back home) Elsa, I know you didn't attend the ball because you didn't have extravagant decorations. That's my oversight. Here is a pair of crystal shoes I got by chance. If you want to attend the ball tomorrow, you can wear these.

content.content: (So happy) I've heard from those who attended that this ball is quite special, with artists from other countries showcasing their art for everyone to appreciate. I'm very interested in art and quite talented. This time, I must wear the beautiful crystal shoes to attend the ball and see what artworks are on display. Let me try on these crystal shoes first.

question: #question#How can Elsa show that she appreciates and loves art?

content.content: (Laughing to herself) Wow, I've heard that there will be artists from other countries displaying their works at the ball, and that really excites me! However, I'm not interested in every piece of art since some styles just aren't my thing. If the artworks at the ball are too avant-garde or difficult for me to understand, it might get a bit boring. Maybe I should look at the list first and decide whether it's really worth my time to appreciate these art pieces. After all, I have my own taste, and not everything captures my attention.

Artists? I think they're just freeloaders with pretentious airs, probably not even as talented as I am. Art is the least interesting. I've heard that the ball will have many artists showcasing their work, and I actually find that intriguing. But honestly, I'm quite knowledgeable about art myself, and my works might even rival theirs. I might not pay too much attention to their pieces since they might not teach me anything new. Perhaps I should consider showcasing my own work so that people can see what true value in art is.
(Speechless, pondering for a moment):
I actually don't want to go that much either. Cinderella cried yesterday, and maybe going to the ball would cheer her up a bit. I should get ready and sneak over to tell her the good news.

question: #question#If Elsa remembers Cinderella crying last night, what might she do?

content.content: (Hesitating slightly) I don't really feel like going to the ball. Cinderella has been quite sad recently, but... do I really want to give her the crystal shoes? I have a lot to do now, and maybe I don't need to purposely seek her out. She'll find out eventually, and when she feels better, she'll come around on her own. Honestly, whether I go or not doesn't really make a big difference.

It was indeed heart-wrenching to see Cinderella cry yesterday. Maybe I should tell her the news? But her emotions have been quite unstable lately, and what if she doesn't want to listen when I find her? Maybe I should go to the ball first and consider finding her afterwards. By then, I might bring back some stories from the ball to comfort her. Would that be better?

Cinderella has indeed been down lately, but if I go to her, she might feel like I'm pitying her. Maybe it's best not to meddle too much, after all, she needs her own space too. Going to the ball might let me meet other people, and maybe through someone else, she can learn this news. That way, she might feel better. Facing her directly might make her feel more awkward.

dialog.content: (In the evening, Elsa had dressed up elaborately and was about to leave for the ball when she ran into Cinderella, who had just returned from work. Cinderella looked at Elsa's shoes with disbelief.) Those shoes... they're indeed very beautiful, very beautiful. Go ahead.

(Elsa had a wonderful time at the ball and fell asleep as soon as she got home. The next day, she didn't see Cinderella at all, so she decided to check on her in her room.) Cinderella? Cinderella? What's wrong with you? Why have you been lying in bed all day? Cinderella? Can you hear me? Someone come quickly!

Cinderella committed suicide with sleeping pills, leaving a letter on the bedside saying she never expected that she treated Elsa as a friend, but Elsa stole the crystal shoes left by her late mother. She was heartbroken. Elsa learned the truth, was unable to accept that her father had stolen Cinderella's shoes for her to wear, indirectly causing Cinderella's death, and thus she severed ties with her father and turned herself in.

(Elsa sneaks into Cinderella's room while her stepmother and stepsisters are distracted, handing over the glass slipper and explaining her reason, having an identical pair herself) Thank you, Elsa, but hold on a minute, something feels off. I have an identical pair of glass slippers here, let me show you.
(Elsa is shocked that Cinderella has something so valuable) Really? Sure, let me take a look.

(Cinderella searches her bedroom but can't find them, and comes out dejected) Ugh, I've been searching deep in my wardrobe for ages but couldn't find them. These shoes were left to me by my birth mother, only my father knew about them. So, did my father give these to you? Did he steal my shoes to give them to you?

Upon hearing the truth, Elsa fainted in shock; she never imagined that the father she always respected could do such a thing. Consequently, she fell seriously ill and was bedridden, while Cinderella, utterly disappointed in her father, left home and decided to wander the world.
Thank you, I can tell that you've been silently helping me all along.

(Elsa felt a bit embarrassed too, and to comfort Cinderella, she started talking about some happy things. Cinderella is quite nostalgic, so the happy memories she brought up were from long ago. The moonlight filled the courtyard, and only their cheerful laughter could be heard. Elsa and Cinderella chatted the whole night until the ball was about to end and they finally bid each other farewell.) They're going to be back soon, let's hurry and get to bed, or we'll be caught having fun on our own.
Okay! Thank you, Elsa! Tonight is the happiest I've been since my mother passed away.
I feel for you, stay strong, everything will get better, keep going!

From then on, Elsa and Cinderella formed a subtle friendship at home, and whenever Cinderella was bullied, Elsa would find ways to help her out of trouble. Years later, both of them married the love of their lives, and although life was a bit tough, it was incredibly happy.
